item.title:
I feel a need to make my own Mac mail client. Yes, they are "the thing" to be making at the moment. But all the recent ones (Sparrow, Airmail, etc), start from the wrong point - the default Mail.app client.
I'd like to start from "mutt" and work out from there. No, it won't be the client for everyone, and yes, it will be graphical. But it won't have "be pretty" as its primary objective. Its objective will be "better".
* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutt_%28e-mail_client%29
item.description:
I feel a need to make my own Mac mail client. Yes, they are "the thing" to be making at the moment. But all the recent ones (Sparrow, Airmail, etc), start from the wrong point - the default Mail.app client.
I'd like to start from "mutt" and work out from there. No, it won't be the client for everyone, and yes, it will be graphical. But it won't have "be pretty" as its primary objective. Its objective will be "better".
* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutt_%28e-mail_client%29

item.title:
Did I mention that Firefox rocks! Never mind all that Chrome and Opera browsers! I do wish Apple would open up the "sharing and reading list APIs" to everyone, as I do miss those features from Safari.
http://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/new/
item.description:

item.title:
We just read a great article that looks at how advertisers are tracking you online. HP Labs propose that advertisers should pay people in exchange for their individual data. Hey, that's what CAYOVA does!!
Don't worry, the people writing the article worked that out too and mentioned us!
Have a read:
http://www.fastcompany.com/3009655/tech-forecast/advertisers-profit-by-tracking-you-heres-how-to-benefit-from-tracking-yourself
item.description:
